3,154,572 people displacedhttps://refugeesmigrants.un.org/more-3-million-displaced-yemen-%E2%80%93-joint-un-agency-report }} {{use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Yemeni Crisis (2011–present)}} The '''Yemeni Civil War''' is an ongoing conflict that began in 2015 between two factions claiming to constitute the [[Yemen]]i government, along with their supporters and allies.{{cite news|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/143295/asher-orkaby/houthi-who|agency=Foreign Affairs|title=Houthi Who?|first=Asher|last=Orkaby|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} [[Houthis|Houthi]] forces controlling the capital [[Sana'a]] and allied with forces loyal to the former president [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] have clashed with forces loyal to the government of [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi]], based in [[Aden]]. [[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] (AQAP) and the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] have also carried out attacks, with AQAP controlling swaths of territory in the hinterlands, and along stretches of the coast.{{cite web|title=Yemen in Crisis|url=http://www.cfr.org/yemen/yemen-crisis/p36488|publisher=Council on Foreign Relations|date=8 July 2015}} On 21 March, after [[Houthi takeover in Yemen|taking over Sana'a and the Yemeni government]], the Houthi-led [[Supreme Revolutionary Committee]] declared a general mobilization to overthrow Hadi and further their control by driving into southern provinces.{{cite web|url=http://www.yemenobserver.com/front-page/1397-supreme-revolutionary-commission-declares-general-mobilization.html |title=Yemen observer |author=Abdul-Aziz Oudah |publisher= |accessdate=18 November 2015 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The Houthi offensive, allied with military forces loyal to Saleh, began on the next day with fighting in Lahj governorate. By 25 March, [[Lahij]] fell to the Houthis and they reached the outskirts of Aden, the seat of power for Hadi's government;{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com/news/world/2015/03/25/yemen-president-hadi-flees-aden-palace-as-houthi-rebels-near-officials-say.html|agency=The Toronto Star|title=Yemen’s president flees Aden as rebels close in|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} Hadi fled the country the same day.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/26/hadi-saudi-riyadh_n_6948558.html|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Saudi Arabia: Yemen's President Hadi Arrives In Saudi Capital Riyadh|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/abed-rabbo-mansour-hadi-yemen-leader-flees-country-1.3008452|agency=CBS.CA|title=Abed Rabbo Mansour Hadi, Yemen leader, flees country|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}} Concurrently, a coalition led by [[Saudi Arabia]] launched [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|military operations]] by using airstrikes to restore the former [[Yemeni government]] and the [[United States]] provided intelligence and logistical support for the campaign. According to the [[UN]], from March 2015 to August 2016, over 10,000 people have been killed in Yemen, including 3,799 civilians. == Background == {{main article|Houthi insurgency in Yemen|Houthi takeover in Yemen|Aftermath of the Houthi takeover in Yemen}} Ansar Allah (sometimes Anglicised as Ansarullah), known popularly as the [[Houthis]], a [[Zaidiyyah|Zaidi]] group with its origins in the mountainous [[Sa'dah Governorate]] on Yemen's northern border with [[Saudi Arabia]], began waging a low-level [[Houthi insurgency in Yemen|insurgency]] against the [[government of Yemen|Yemeni government]] in 2004.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3643600.stm|agency=BBC News|title=Yemeni forces kill rebel cleric|date=10 September 2004|accessdate=9 April 2015}} The intensity of the conflict waxed and waned over the course of the [[2000s (decade)|2000s]], with multiple peace agreements being negotiated and later disregarded. {{cite news|url=http://legacy.utsandiego.com/news/world/20070129-0318-yemen-houthi-.html|agency=San Diego Union-Tribune|title=Yemen tells Shi'ite rebels to disband or face war|date=29 January 2007|accessdate=9 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/yemens-government-shiite-rebels-negotiate-end-to-3-year-conflict/|agency=The Seattle Times|title=Yemen’s government, Shiite rebels negotiate end to 3-year conflict|date=17 June 2007|accessdate=9 April 2015}} The Houthi insurgency [[Operation Scorched Earth|heated up]] in 2009, briefly drawing in neighbouring Saudi Arabia on the side of the Yemeni government, but quieted the following year after a ceasefire was signed.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2010/01/2010127124547864341.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Saudi-Houthi border fighting ends|date=27 January 2010|accessdate=9 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2015/01/22/who-are-the-houthis-the-group-that-just-toppled-yemens-government/|agency=The Washington Post|title=Who are the Houthis, the group that just toppled Yemen’s government?|date=22 January 2015|accessdate=9 April 2015|first=Adam|last=Taylor}} During the early stages of the [[Yemeni Revolution]] in 2011, Houthi leader [[Abdul-Malik al-Houthi]] declared the group's support for demonstrations calling for the resignation of President [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/21/yemen.protests/|agency=CNN|title=Yemen's president compares protests to 'influenza'|date=21 February 2011|accessdate=9 April 2015}} Later in the year, as Saleh prepared to leave office, the Houthis [[Siege of Dammaj|laid siege]] to the [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]]-majority village of [[Dammaj]] in northern Yemen, a step toward attaining virtual autonomy for Sa'dah.{{cite news|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/2199|agency=Al-Akhbar|title=Post-Saleh Yemen: A Brewing Battle Between Houthis and Salafis|date=5 December 2011|accessdate=9 April 2015|first=Jamal|last=Jubran}} The Houthis boycotted a [[Yemeni presidential election, 2012|single-candidate election]] in early 2012 meant to give [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi]] a two-year term of office.{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-02-14/yemen-s-houthi-rebels-vow-to-boycott-presidential-elections|agency=Bloomberg|title=Yemen’s Houthi Rebels Vow to Boycott Presidential Elections|first=Mohammed|last=Hatem|date=14 February 2012|accessdate=9 April 2015}} They participated in a [[National Dialogue Conference]], but withheld support from a final accord in early 2014 that extended Hadi's mandate in office for another year.{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1749/news/3391/Houthis-throw-a-wrench-in-NDC-final-document.htm|agency=Yemen Times|title=HOUTHIS THROW A WRENCH IN NDC FINAL DOCUMENT|first=Mohammed|last=Al-Hassani|date=23 January 2014|accessdate=9 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1853/news/4830/Cabinet-and-Hadi-resign.htm|agency=Yemen Times|title=CABINET AND HADI RESIGN|date=22 January 2015|accessdate=9 April 2015}} Meanwhile, the conflict between the Houthis and Sunni tribes in northern Yemen spread to other governorates, including the [[Sana'a Governorate]] by mid-2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1813/report/4294/The-Houthis-From-a-local-group-to-a-national-power.htm|agency=Yemen Times|title=THE HOUTHIS: FROM A LOCAL GROUP TO A NATIONAL POWER|first=Ali Ibrahim|last=Al-Moshki|date=4 September 2014|accessdate=9 April 2015}} After several weeks of street protests against the Hadi administration, which made cuts to fuel subsidies that were unpopular with the group, the Houthis came to blows with [[Yemen Army]] forces under the command of General [[Ali Mohsen al-Ahmar]]. In a [[Battle of Sana'a (2014)|battle]] that lasted only a few days, Houthi fighters seized control of [[Sana'a]], the Yemeni capital, in September 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/fr/in-depth/features/yemenis-are-shocked-houthi-s-quick-capture-sanaa-690971750|agency=Middle East Eye|title=Yemenis are shocked by Houthis' quick capture of Sana'a|date=September 2014|accessdate=9 April 2015|first=Saeed|last=Al-Batati}} The Houthis forced Hadi to negotiate an agreement to end the violence, in which the government resigned and the Houthis gained an unprecedented level of influence over state institutions and politics.{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/09/21/Clashes-in-Yemeni-capital-cast-doubt-on-deal-signing.html|agency=Al Arabiya|title=Houthis sign deal with Sanaa to end Yemen crisis|date=21 September 2014|accessdate=9 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/21/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0HG04T20140921|agency=Reuters|title=Houthi rebels sign deal with Yemen parties to form new government|date=21 September 2014|accessdate=9 April 2015|first=Mohammed|last=Ghobari}} In January 2015, unhappy with a proposal to split the country into six federal regions,{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21640384-houthi-rebels-carry-out-coup-all-name-held-hostage|agency=The Economist|title=Held hostage|date=24 January 2015|accessdate=9 April 2015}} Houthi fighters [[2014–15 Yemeni coup d'état|seized the presidential compound]] in Sana'a. The power play prompted the resignation of President [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi]] and his ministers.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/26/world/middleeast/yemeni-parliament-cancels-meeting-on-presidents-resignation.html?_r=0|author=Mona El-naggar|title=Shifting Alliances Play Out Behind Closed Doors in Yemen|date=25 January 2015|website=New York Times|accessdate=15 February 2015}} The Houthi political leadership then announced the dissolution of [[House of Representatives (Yemen)|parliament]] and the formation of a [[Revolutionary Committee (Yemen)|Revolutionary Committee]] to govern the country on 6 February 2015.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/07/us-yemen-crisis-idUSKBN0LA1NT20150207|agency=Reuters|title=Yemen's Houthis dissolve parliament, assume power: televised statement|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=9 February 2015}} On 21 February, one month after Houthi militants confined Hadi to his residence in Sana'a, he slipped out of the capital and traveled to [[Aden]]. In a televised address from his hometown, he declared that the Houthi takeover was illegitimate and indicated he remained the constitutional president of Yemen.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/02/21/world/yemen-unrest/index.html|publisher=CNN|title=Yemen's Hadi flees house arrest, plans to withdraw resignation|date=21 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/02/yemen-leader-hadi-leaves-sanaa-weeks-house-arrest-150221090018174.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen's Hadi says Houthis decisions unconstitutional|date=21 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/World/2015/02/22/Yemens-ousted-president-Hadi-calls-for-Houthis-to-quit-capital/|work=The Star|title=Yemen's ousted president Hadi calls for Houthis to quit capital|date=22 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}} His predecessor as president, [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]]—who had been widely suspected of aiding the Houthis during their takeover of Sana'a the previous year—publicly denounced Hadi and called on him to go into exile.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/03/yemen-leader-asks-president-hadi-exile-150310134751759.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Ex-Yemen leader asks President Hadi to go into exile|date=10 March 2015|accessdate=11 March 2015}} ===Allegations of outside support=== The Houthis have long been accused of being proxies for [[Iran]], since they both follow [[Shia Islam]]. (Although the Iranians are Twelve-Imam Shias and the Houthis are [[Zaidis|Five-Imam Shias]].) The [[United States]] and [[Saudi Arabia]] have alleged that the Houthis receive weapons and training from Iran.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-32229316|agency=BBC News|title=Yemen crisis: Kerry warns Iran over Houthi rebel 'support'|date=9 April 2015|accessdate=9 April 2015}} The Houthis and Iranian government have denied any affiliation.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/15/us-yemen-houthis-iran-insight-idUSKBN0JT17A20141215|agency=Reuters|title=Iranian support seen crucial for Yemen's Houthis|date=15 December 2014|accessdate=19 February 2015}} The [[Africa]]n nation of [[Eritrea]] has also been accused of funneling Iranian material to the Houthis,{{cite news|url=http://www.turkishweekly.net/news/182683/eritrea-denies-channeling-iranian-support-to-houthis.html|agency=The Journal of Turkish Weekly|title=Eritrea denies channeling Iranian support to Houthis|date=1 April 2015|accessdate=9 April 2015}} as well as offering medical care for injured Houthi fighters.{{cite news|url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/haber/152737/houthi-rise-in-yemen-raises-alarm-in-horn-of-africa|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=9 April 2015|title=Houthi rise in Yemen raises alarm in Horn of Africa|agency=World Bulletin}} The Eritrean government has called the allegations "groundless" and said after the outbreak of open hostilities that it views the Yemeni crisis "as an internal matter". Documents from wikileaks suggest that privately US officials believe that allegations of Iranian support for the Houthis have been overstated by the Yemeni Government for political reasons.{{cite web|url=https://wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/09SANAA1662_a.html|title=Cable: 09SANAA1662_a|work=wikileaks.org}} The Yemeni government, meanwhile, has enjoyed significant international backing from the United States and Persian Gulf monarchies. U.S. drone strikes were conducted regularly in Yemen during Hadi's presidency in [[Sana'a]], usually targeting [[Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]].{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/aug/6/al-qaeda-on-rise-despite-us-support-to-yemen/|agency=The Washington Times|title=Al Qaeda on rise despite U.S. support to Yemen|first=Kristina|last=Wong|date=6 August 2013|accessdate=9 April 2015}} The United States was also a major supplier of weapons to the Yemeni government, although according to the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]], hundreds of millions of [[United States dollar|dollars]]' worth of that material has gone missing since it was delivered. Saudi Arabia provided financial aid to Yemen until late 2014, when it suspended it amid the Houthis' [[Battle of Sana'a (2014)|takeover of Sana'a]] and increasing influence over the Yemeni government.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/04/us-yemen-saudi-aid-idUSKCN0JI10V20141204|agency=Reuters|title=Exclusive: Saudi suspends aid to Yemen after Houthi takeover – sources|date=12 December 2014|accessdate=9 April 2015}} In 2015 [[Sipilä Cabinet]], the government of [[Finland]], accepted selling of [[Sako TRG]] M10 [[sniper rifles]] by 77 million euros to United Arab Emirates, by 2,3 million euros to Bahrain, by one million euros to Jordan and by 24 000 euros to Kuwait.{{cite news|last=Nieminen|first=Tommi|date=2016-10-23|title=Sipilän hallitus siunasi sotilaskiväärien kaupat sortovaltio Turkmenistaniin ja Jemenissä sotiviin arabimaihin – Miksi Suomen linja muuttui?|url=http://www.hs.fi/sunnuntai/a1477023875631|language=Finnish|newspaper=Helsingin Sanomat|location=Helsinki|access-date=2016-10-24}} ==Timeline== ===Conflict begins=== {{see also|Battle of Aden Airport|2015 Sana'a mosque bombings}} Troops loyal to Hadi clashed with those who refused to recognise his authority in a [[Battle of Aden Airport|battle]] for [[Aden International Airport]] on 19 March 2015. The forces under General [[Abdul-Hafez al-Saqqaf]] were defeated, and al-Saqqaf himself reportedly fled toward Sana'a.{{cite news|url=http://en.arabstoday.net/news/interview/yemen-anti-hadi-officer-escapes-assassination.html|agency=Arab Today|title=Yemen anti-Hadi officer 'escapes assassination'|date=20 March 2015|accessdate=31 March 2015}} In apparent retaliation for the routing of al-Saqqaf, warplanes reportedly flown by Houthi pilots bombed Hadi's compound in Aden.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/19/aden-presidential-palace-bombed_n_6901722.html|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Warplanes Bomb Presidential Palace In Yemen's Aden|date=19 March 2015|accessdate=31 March 2015|first=Hamza|last=Hendawi}} [[File:Aden,Yemen Port.jpg|thumbnail|left|Aden]] After the [[2015 Sana'a mosque bombings]] on 20 March 2015, in a televised speech, [[Abdul-Malik al-Houthi]], the leader of the Houthis, said his group's decision to mobilize for war was "imperative" under current circumstances and that [[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] and its affiliates—among whom he counts Hadi—would be targeted, as opposed to southern Yemen and its citizens.{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1870/news/4994/Southerners-prepare-for-Houthi-invasion.htm|title=SOUTHERNERS PREPARE FOR HOUTHI INVASION|first=Khalid|last=Al-Karimi|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015|agency=Yemen Times}} President Hadi declared Aden to be Yemen's temporary capital while [[Sana'a]] remained under Houthi control.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/afp-beleaguered-hadi-says-aden-yemen-capital-2015-3|agency=Business Insider|title=Beleaguered Hadi says Aden Yemen 'capital'|date=7 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}{{cite news|last=Tejas |first=Aditya|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/yemeni-president-abed-rabbo-mansour-hadi-flees-aden-houthis-advance-1858514|title=Yemeni President Abed Rabbo Mansour Hadi Flees Aden As Houthis Advance|date=25 March 2015}} [[File:Saudi soldier from the First Brigade Airborne near to Emirates soldier.jpg|thumb|Saudi soldier from the First Brigade Airborne near to Emirates soldier]] Also, the same day as the mosque bombings, al-Qaeda militants captured the provincial capital of [[Lahij]], [[al-Houta district|Al-Houta]], after killing about 20 soldiers, before being driven out several hours later.{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/21/yemen-mosque-bombings-enemies-of-life-president-abedrabbo-mansour-hadi-houthi-isis-al-qaida|title=Yemen mosque bombings 'could only be done by the enemies of life' – president|work=the Guardian}} ====Political developments==== Hadi reiterated in a speech on 21 March that he was the legitimate president of Yemen and declared, "We will restore security to the country and hoist the flag of Yemen in Sana'a, instead of the Iranian flag."{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/22/us-yemen-security-fighting-idUSKBN0MH0F820150322|agency=Reuters|title=Yemeni president demands Houthis quit Sanaa; U.S. evacuates remaining forces|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} He also officially declared Aden to be Yemen's "economic and temporary capital" due to the Houthi occupation of Sana'a, which he pledged would be retaken.{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/yemens-president-hadi-declares-new-temporary-capital/a-18332197|publisher=Deutsche Welle|title=Yemen's President Hadi declares new 'temporary capital'|date=21 March 2015|accessdate=21 March 2015}} In [[Sana'a]], the Houthi [[Revolutionary Committee (Yemen)|Revolutionary Committee]] appointed Major General [[Hussein Khairan]] as Yemen's new defence minister and placed him in overall command of the military offensive.{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1870/news/4993/Houthis-appoint-new-defense-minister.htm|agency=The Yemen Times|title=HOUTHIS APPOINT NEW DEFENSE MINISTER|first=Fareed|last=Al-Homaid|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=31 March 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-03-22/yemen-rebels-send-tanks-south-as-conflict-escalates|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=31 March 2015|title=Rebel Fighters Advance Into Yemen’s Third-Largest City|agency=Bloomberg}} === Control of Taiz === {{main article|Battle of Taiz (2015–2016)}} Houthi forces backed by troops loyal to Saleh entered [[Taiz]], Yemen's third-largest city, on 22 March and quickly took over key points in the city. They encountered little resistance, although one protester was shot dead and five more were injured.{{cite news|url = http://www.rfi.fr/moyen-orient/20150322-yemen-milices-houthis-pression-president-mansour-hadi-taez/|agency = RFI|language = French|title = Yémen: les milices houthis prennent le contrôle de l’aéroport de Taëz|date = 22 March 2015|accessdate = 25 March 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/22/houthi-yemen-fighting_n_6918306.html|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Houthis Seize Strategic City In Yemen, Escalating Power Struggle|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} [[Western world|Western]] media outlets began to suggest Yemen was sliding into civil war as the Houthis from the north confronted holdouts in the south.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/faa645dc-d0b2-11e4-982a-00144feab7de.html|agency=Financial Times|title=Q&A: Yemen’s slide into civil war|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=8 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2015/03/envoy-yemen-brink-civil-war-150322212545073.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=UN envoy: Yemen on brink of civil war|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=10 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/25/yemen-edges-towards-all-out-civil-war-as-rebels-advance-on-city-of-aden|agency=The Guardian|title=Yemen edges towards all-out civil war as rebels advance on city of Aden|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=10 April 2015|first=Kareem|last=Shaheen}} ====Western Yemen advance==== On 23 March 2015, Houthi forces advanced towards the strategic [[Bab-el-Mandeb]] strait, a vital corridor through which much of the world’s maritime trade passes.{{cite news|url=http://www.thenational.ae/world/yemens-houthi-rebels-move-on-strategic-gulf-waterway|title=Yemen’s Houthi rebels move on strategic Gulf waterway|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015|agency=The National}} The next day, fighters from the group reportedly entered the port of [[Mocha, Yemen|Mocha]].{{cite news|title=Yemen’s Ansarullah fighters enter port of Mocha, two towns in south|agency=Iran Daily|url=http://www.iran-daily.com/News/114322.html?catid=3&title{{=}}Yemen-s-Ansarullah-fighters-enter-port-of-Mocha--two-towns-in-south|date=24 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentid=20150325238084 |agency=Saudi Gazette |title=Key waterway under threat as Houthi militiamen advance |accessdate=25 March 2015 |date=24 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402133812/http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentid=20150325238084 |archivedate=2 April 2015 }} On 31 March, Houthi fighters entered a coastal military base on the strait after the 17th Armoured Division of the Yemen Army opened the gates and turned over weapons to them.{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-03-31/yemen-rebels-seize-base-near-shipping-lane-as-saudis-target-aden|agency=Bloomberg|title=Saudi Coalition Hits Houthi Stronghold as Aden Battle Rages|date=31 March 2015|accessdate=1 April 2015}} On 2 April, [[Mahamoud Ali Youssouf]], the foreign minister of [[Djibouti]], said the Houthis placed heavy weapons and fast attack boats on [[Perim]] and a smaller island in the Bab-el-Mandeb strait. He warned that the weapons posed "a big danger" to his country, commercial shipping traffic, and military vessels.{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-02/yemeni-rebels-strengthen-positions-in-key-strait-djibouti-says|agency=Bloomberg|first=Paul|last=Richardson|date=2 April 2015|accessdate=2 April 2015|title=Yemeni Rebels Strengthen Positions at Entrance to Red Sea}} === Southern offensive === ====Battle of Dhale==== {{Main article|Battle of Dhale}} Houthi forces [[Battle of Dhale|seized]] administrative buildings in Dhale (or Dali) amid heavy fighting on 24 March, bringing them closer to Aden.{{cite news|url=http://www.romandie.com/news/Les-forces-hostiles-au-president-resserrent-l039etau/577912.rom|title=Les forces hostiles au président resserrent l'étau sur Aden|agency=Romandie|date=24 March 2015|accessdate=24 March 2015|language=French}} However, Houthi fighters were swiftly dislodged from Ad Dali' and Kirsh by Hadi-loyal forces.{{cite news|title=Hadi forces check Houthi push towards Yemen's Aden|agency=Reuters|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/24/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0MK16O20150324|date=24 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} Fighting over Dhale continued even as the Houthis advanced further south and east. On 31 March, Hadi loyalists clashed with the Houthis and army units loyal to Saleh.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/31/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0MR0HE20150331|agency=Reuters|title=Heavy clashes on Saudi-Yemeni border; Hadi government pleads for troops|date=31 March 2015|accessdate=31 March 2015}} The next day, a pro-Houthi army brigade was said to have "disintegrated" after being pummeled by coalition warplanes in Ad Dali. The commander of the 33rd Brigade reportedly fled, and groups of pro-Houthi troops withdrew to the north.{{cite news|url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/todays-news/157273/pro-houthi-brigade-disintegrates-in-yemens-ad-dali|agency=World Bulletin|title=Pro-Houthi brigade disintegrates in Yemen's Ad Dali|date=1 April 2015|accessdate=1 April 2015}} [[File:Three F-15C Saudi from 13 Squadron.jpg|thumb|Three F-15C Saudi from 13th Squadron]] The city reportedly fell into pro-government hands by the end of May.{{cite news|work=The Record|url=http://www.northjersey.com/news/yemen-s-pro-government-forces-retake-city-from-shite-rebels-1.1342386|title=Yemen's pro-government forces retake city from Shite rebels|date=26 May 2015|accessdate=29 May 2015}} ====Fighting in Lahij==== {{see also|Lahij insurgency}} In the [[Lahij Governorate]], heavy fighting erupted between Houthis and pro-Hadi fighters on 24 March. The next day, [[Al Anad Air Base]], 60 kilometers from Aden, was captured by the Houthis and their allies. The base had recently been abandoned by [[United States of America]] [[US SOCOM]] troops.{{cite news|url=http://www.lorientlejour.com/article/917483/yemen-les-forces-hostiles-au-president-semparent-dune-base-proche-daden-militaire.html|title=Yémen : les forces hostiles au président s'emparent d'une base proche d'Aden (militaire)|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015|agency=L'Orient Le Jour|language=French}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/26/world/middleeast/al-anad-air-base-houthis-yemen.html?_r=0|title=Yemen Air Base Formerly Used by U.S. Forces Is Seized by Houthi Rebels|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015|agency=NYtimes}} Defence Minister [[Mahmoud al-Subaihi]], one of Hadi's top lieutenants, was captured by the Houthis in [[Al Houta District|Al Houta]] and transferred to Sana'a.{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1871/news/4999/Al-Subaihi-captured-and-Lahj-falls-as-Houthis-move-on-Aden.htm|agency=Yemen Times|title=AL-SUBAIHI CAPTURED AND LAHJ FALLS AS HOUTHIS MOVE ON ADEN|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/yemens-president-hadi-flees-houthi-rebel-advance-aden-ap-n329761|title=Yemen's President Hadi Flees Houthi Rebel Advance on Aden: AP|agency=nbcnews|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}} Houthi fighters also advanced to Dar Saad, a small town, 20 km north of Aden.{{cite news|agency=L'Orient Le Jour|url=http://www.lorientlejour.com/article/917540/des-tirs-signales-a-aden-les-houthis-a-20-km.html|title=Des tirs signalés à Aden, les Houthis à 20 km|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015|language=French}} On 26 March, after [[Battle of Aden|clashes erupted in Aden]], Hadi loyalists counterattacked as a [[Saudi-led intervention in Yemen (2015–present)|Saudi-led military intervention]] got underway. Artillery shelled [[Al Anad Air Base]], forcing some of its Houthi occupants to flee the area.{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Breaking-News/Yemen-presidents-forces-shell-Houthi-held-al-Anad-base-near-Aden-some-Houthis-flee-395155|agency=The Jerusalem Post|title=Yemen president's forces shell Houthi-held al-Anad base near Aden, some Houthis flee|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}} [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]] airstrikes also hit Al Anad.{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/article16355684.html |agency=Miami Herald |title=Saudi airstrikes target rebel bases in Yemen |date=26 March 2015 |accessdate=26 March 2015 |first=Ahmed |last=Al-Haj |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402162022/http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/article16355684.html |archivedate=2 April 2015 }} Despite the airstrikes, however, the southern offensive continued.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/27/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0ML0YC20150327|agency=Reuters|title=Saudi-led campaign strikes Yemen's Sanaa, Morocco joins alliance|first=Mohammed|last=Mukhashaf|date=27 March 2015|accessdate=27 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/03/28/yemen-security-idUKL6N0WT2R220150328|title=WRAPUP 6-Yemen Houthi rebels advance despite Saudi-led air strikes|work=Reuters UK}} ===Fighting reaches Aden=== {{Main article|Battle of Aden}} In Aden, military officials said militias and [[military unit]]s loyal to Hadi had "fragmented" by 25 March, speeding the [[rebellion|rebel]] advance. They said the rebels were fighting Hadi's troops on five different fronts.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2015/Mar-25/292101-yemens-president-hadi-has-fled-aden-home-as-houthi-rebels-close-in-officials.ashx|title=Yemen's Houthis close in on Aden|agency=The Daily Star|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} [[Aden International Airport]] suspended all flights.{{cite news|language=French|url=http://www.lorientlejour.com/article/917523/yemen-fermeture-de-laeroport-daden-pour-des-raisons-de-securite-source-aeropotuaire.html|title=Yémen : fermeture de l'aéroport d'Aden pour des raisons de sécurité (source aéropotuaire)|agency=L'Orient Le Jour|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} [[Battle of Aden|Fighting reached Aden's outskirts]] on 25 March, with pro-Saleh soldiers taking over [[Aden International Airport]] and clashes erupting at an army base.{{cite news|agency=Le Figaro|language=French|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2015/03/25/97001-20150325FILWWW00332-l-aeroport-d-aden-aux-mains-des-milices-chiites.php|title=L'aéroport d'Aden aux mains des milices chiites|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/03/25/uk-yemen-security-idUKKBN0ML0YM20150325|first=Sami|last=Aboudi|title=Allies of Yemen Houthis seize Aden airport, close in on president|agency=Reuters|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} Hadi reportedly fled his "temporary capital" by boat as the unrest worsened. The next day, he resurfaced in the Saudi capital, [[Riyadh]], where he arrived by plane and was met by Saudi Prince [[Mohammad bin Salman Al Saud]]. Over the following days, Houthi and allied army forces encircled Aden{{cite news|agency=Reuters|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/27/us-yemen-security-seaboard-idUSKBN0MN21620150327|title=Yemen Houthi forces gain first foothold on Arabian Sea – residents|date=27 March 2015|accessdate=27 March 2015|first=Noah|last=Browning}}{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/saudi-arabia-evacuates-diplomats-as-attacks-intensify-in-yemen/2015/03/28/627dc24a-d4d0-11e4-8b1e-274d670aa9c9_story.html|agency=The Washington Post|title=Saudi Arabia evacuates diplomats as attacks intensify in Yemen|date=28 March 2015|accessdate=28 March 2015}} and hemmed in Hadi's holdouts, although they encountered fierce resistance from the embattled president's loyalists and armed city residents. They began pressing into the city center on 29 March despite coalition airstrikes and shelling from [[Egyptian Navy]] warships offshore.{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/clashes-continue-yemens-aden-saudis-vow-continue-airstrikes-1237969720|publisher=middleeasteye|title=Clashes continue in Yemen's Aden as Saudis vow to push on with airstrikes|date=30 March 2015|accessdate=30 March 2015}} On 2 April, the compound that has been used as a temporary presidential palace was taken by the Houthis,{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-32157994|title=Yemen crisis: Rebels storm presidential palace in Aden|date=2 April 2015|accessdate=2 April 2015}} and fighting moved into the central [[Crater (Aden)|Crater]] and [[Al Mualla District|Al Mualla]] districts.{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/news/world/article/Pakistan-says-Saudi-led-coalition-in-Yemen-wants-6180919.php |agency=Houston Chronicle |title=Fierce fighting as rebels move on holdouts in Yemen's Aden |date=6 April 2015 |accessdate=6 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150406215725/http://www.chron.com/news/world/article/Pakistan-says-Saudi-led-coalition-in-Yemen-wants-6180919.php |archivedate=6 April 2015 }} A small contingent of foreign troops were reportedly deployed in Aden by early May, fighting alongside anti-Houthi militiamen in the city. [[Saudi Arabia]] denied the presence of [[Saudi-led military intervention in Yemen (2015-present)|ground troops]],{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/saudi-arabia-led-troops-in-limited-first-yemen-deployment/article1-1343666.aspx|agency=Hindustan Times|title=Saudi Arabia-led troops in 'limited' first Yemen deployment|date=4 May 2015|accessdate=4 May 2015}} while Hadi's government claimed the troops were Yemeni special forces who had received training in the [[Gulf Cooperation Council|Persian Gulf]] and were redeployed to fight in Aden.{{cite news|first=Angus|last=McDowall|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/04/yemen-security-idUSL5N0XV1VI20150504|agency=Reuters|title=Yemen's foreign minister: Aden troops were Gulf-trained locals|date=4 May 2015|accessdate=4 May 2015}} It is reported that forces loyal to Hadi have recaptured Aden with support from the Saudi Arabian government, this has allowed supplies to finally reach the port city giving civilians well needed aid. Pro-government fighters fully recaptured Aden from Houthi fighters on 21 July in Operation Golden Arrow after months of fighting. At this point, the pro-government fighters had recaptured more than 90% of the Province of Aden . On 22 July a Saudi military plane landed in Aden international airport filled with relief aid. On 21 July, a U.N. ship docked in Aden carrying much-needed relief supplies, the first U.N. vessel to reach the city in four months. Another ship sent by the UAE also delivered medical aid. On 21 July a UAE technical team had arrived to repair the tower and passenger terminal at Aden international airport, heavily damaged in clashes. On 24 July a military plane from the UAE arrived filled with relief aid.{{cite web|url=http://rudaw.net/english/middleeast/230720152|title=Saudi-backed Yemeni troops and fighters control Aden|work=Rudaw|accessdate=25 September 2015}} On 4 August, Houthi rebels were pushed back from the Al-Anad airbase, by Pro-Hadi forces.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-33778116|agency=BBC|title=Yemen war: Does capture of air base mark a turning point?|date=4 August 2015|accessdate=12 August 2015}} On 17 October, Saudi Arabia confirmed the arrival of Sudanese troops into Aden for the purpose of bolstering the Saudi-led coalition.{{cite news|agency=Sudan Tribune|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article56758|title=Saudi Arabia confirms arrival of Sudanese troops to Yemen|date=17 October 2015|accessdate=20 October 2015}}{{cite news|agency=Sudan Tribune|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article56779|title=Sudan to send 10,000 troops to join Arab forces in Yemen: report|date=19 October 2015|accessdate=20 October 2015}} In January 2016, new [[Aden unrest (2015–present)|conflict]] began in Aden, with ISIL and AQAP controlling neighborhoods in the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2016/Feb-22/338534-yemen-army-commander-shot-dead-in-aden.ashx|title=Yemen army commander shot dead in Aden|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon}} ===Other campaigns=== ====Abyan Governorate==== {{main article|Abyan campaign (March–August 2015)}} The Houthis racked up a series of victories in the [[Abyan Governorate]] east of Aden in the days following their entrance into Hadi's provisional capital, taking control of [[Shuqrah]] and [[Zinjibar]] on the coast and winning the allegiance of a local army brigade, but they also encountered resistance from both pro-Hadi army brigadiers and [[al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] militants.{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1875/news/5041/Fighting-in-Abyan-governorate-continues-as-anti-Houthi-forces-advance.htm|agency=Yemen Times|title=FIGHTING IN ABYAN GOVERNORATE CONTINUES AS ANTI-HOUTHI FORCES ADVANCE|first=Ali Ibrahim|last=Al-Moshki|date=8 April 2015|accessdate=8 April 2015}} The [[Zinjibar]], [[Jaʿār|Jaar]] [[Fall of Zinjibar and Jaar|recaptured]] by AQAP in 2,of December.{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0TL0BQ20151202|title=Al Qaeda militants take over two south Yemen towns, residents say|author=Mohammed Mukhashaf|date=2 December 2015|work=Reuters}} In 20 February 2016 the southern Abyan also [[Southern Abyan Offensive (2016)|captured]] by AQAP linked them with their headquarters in Al Mukalla.{{cite web|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2016/02/another-town-in-southern-yemen-reportedly-falls-to-aqap.php|title=Another town in southern Yemen reportedly falls to AQAP|work=The Long War Journal}} ====Sana'a Governorate==== As of February 2016, loyalist forces have managed to enter Sana'a governorate by capturing the [[Nihm District]] killing dozens of Houthi fighters. They continued advance capturing some cities and villages.{{cite web|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/saudi-arabia-asks-un-move-aid-workers-away-rebel-held-areas-857537267|title=Saudi Arabia asks UN to move aid workers away from rebel-held areas|work=Middle East Eye}} ====Hadhramaut Governorate==== {{Main article|Battle of Al Mukalla (2015)|Battle of Al Mukalla (2016)}} [[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] took control of [[Al Mukalla]] in the eastern [[Hadhramaut Governorate]] on 2 April, driving out soldiers defending the city with mortar fire and springing some 300 inmates from prison, including a local al Qaeda leader.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/04/world/middleeast/al-qaeda-al-mukalla-yemen.html?_r=0|agency=The New York Times|title=Affiliate of Al Qaeda Seizes Major Yemeni City, Driving Out the Military|date=3 April 2015|accessdate=4 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/yemen-al-qaeda-frees-300-al-mukalla-prison-attack-1494697|agency=International Business Times|title=Yemen: Al-Qaeda frees 300 in al-Mukalla prison attack|date=2 April 2015|accessdate=4 April 2015|first=Umberto|last=Bacchi}} Local tribal fighters aligned with Hadi surrounded and entered Al Mukalla two days later, retaking parts of the city and clashing with both al-Qaeda militants and army troops.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/05/us-yemen-security-airstrikes-idUSKBN0MW03D20150405|agency=Reuters|title=Warplanes hit Yemen's Sanaa overnight, clashes in Mukalla: residents|date=5 April 2015|accessdate=6 April 2015}} Still, the militants remained in control of about half of the town. In addition, al-Qaeda fighters captured a border post with Saudi Arabia in an attack that killed two soldiers.{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/07/us-yemen-security-militants-idUSKBN0MY18F20150407|title=Suspected al Qaeda militants take Yemen border post with Saudi|work=Reuters}} On 13 April 2015, Southern militia said they took control of the army base loyal to the Houthis near [[Balhaf]].{{cite news|author1=MOHAMED MUKASHAF|title=Egypt and Saudi Arabia discuss manoeuvres as Yemen battles rage|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/World/2015/04/15/Fighters-in-southern-Yemen-say-pushing-back-Houthis/|accessdate=15 April 2015|publisher=Star Publications}} Al Mukalla City was recaptured from AQAP in late April 2016, after UAE and Hadi loyalists troops entered the city, killing some 800 AQAP fighters.{{cite web|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2016/04/arab-coalition-enters-aqap-stronghold-in-port-city-of-mukalla-yemen.php |title=Arab coalition enters AQAP stronghold in port city of Mukalla, Yemen |publisher=The Long War Journal |date= |accessdate=2016-06-03}} ====Lahij Governorate==== {{main article|Lahij insurgency}} Although the Houthis took control of [[Lahij]] on the road to [[Aden]], resistance continued in the [[Lahij Governorate]]. Ambushes and bombings struck Houthi supply lines to the [[Battle of Aden|Aden front]], with a landmine killing a reported 25 Houthi fighters on their way to Aden on 28 March.{{cite news|url=http://durdurnews.com/houthi-offensive-continues-in-yemen/|agency=Durdurnews|title=Houthi Offensive Continues in Yemen|date=29 March 2015|accessdate=8 April 2015}}{{Dead link|date=November 2015}} ====Shabwah Governorate==== {{main article|Shabwah campaign (March–August 2015)|Shabwah Governorate offensive (2014-2016)}} Fighting also centered on the [[Shabwa Province]], in the oil-rich [[Usaylan]] region, where [[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] (AQAP) and [[Ansar al-Sharia]] hold sway. On 29 March, 38 were killed in fighting between the Houthis and Sunni tribesmen. Tribal sources confirmed the death toll, and claimed only eight of them were from their side, with the other 30 either Houthis or their allies from the Yemeni military.{{cite news|url=http://news.antiwar.com/2015/03/29/38-killed-as-yemens-houthis-clash-with-tribesmen-in-oil-rich-south/|publisher=anti war|title=38 Killed as Yemen’s Houthis Clash with Tribesmen in Oil Rich South|date=29 March 2015|accessdate=30 March 2015}} On 9 April, the Houthis and their allies seized the provincial capital of [[Ataq]]. The takeover was facilitated by local tribal chiefs and security officials.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/09/yemen-houthis-take-capital_n_7031540.html?ncid=txtlnkusaolp00000592|title=Yemen's Houthis Seize Provincial Capital Despite Saudi-Led Airstrikes|work=The Huffington Post}} AQAP seized Azzan, and Habban in early February 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-idUSKCN0VA1Y0|title=Al Qaeda militants seize southern Yemeni town: residents|author=Reuters Editorial|date=1 February 2016|work=Reuters}}{{cite web|url=https://news.vice.com/article/al-qaeda-is-making-serious-gains-amid-chaos-of-yemens-civil-war|title=Al Qaeda Is Making Serious Gains Amid Chaos of Yemen's Civil War|author=Avi Asher-Schapiro|work=VICE News}} ====Elsewhere==== In the province of [[Ma'rib Governorate|Ma'rib]], six members of [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] tribes were killed during fighting against Houthis on 22 March.{{cite news|url=http://www.rtl.fr/actu/international/yemen-le-conflit-s-etend-7777097083|language=French|title=Yémen : les rebelles chiites prennent Taëz|agency=RTL|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} The next day, 15 Houthis and 5 tribesmen were killed in clashes in the [[Al Bayda Governorate]].{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/news/156896/15-houthis-5-tribesmen-killed-in-clashes-in-yemen|title=15 Houthis, 5 tribesmen killed in clashes in Yemen – Middle East – Worldbulletin News|work=World Bulletin}} During fighting between Hadi loyalists and Houthi militiamen in [[Sana'a]], the [[Ethiopia]]n embassy was reportedly struck by shelling on 3 April. The Ethiopian government said the attack appeared to be unintentional. No injuries at the embassy were reported.{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article54530|agency=Sudan Tribune|title=Attack on Ethiopian embassy in Yemen not deliberate|date=7 April 2015|accessdate=21 April 2015}} Armed tribesmen drove off Houthis who had set up a makeshift camp in southern [[Ibb Governorate]] and seized their weapons on 7 April.{{cite news|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news_opinion/international/middle_east/2015/04/saudi_led_airstrikes_hit_yemens_south_amid_ground|agency=Boston Herald|title=Saudi-led airstrikes hit Yemen's south amid ground fighting|date=7 April 2015|accessdate=7 April 2015}} Between 17 and 18 April, at least 30 people were killed when the Houthis and allied army units attacked a pro-Hadi military base in Taiz. The dead included 8–16 pro-Hadi and 14–19 Houthi fighters,{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20150418-least-27-dead-fighting-yemens-taez/ |title=Flash – At least 27 dead in fighting in Yemen's Taez – France 24 |work=France 24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418202257/http://www.france24.com/en/20150418-least-27-dead-fighting-yemens-taez/ |archivedate=18 April 2015 }}{{cite web|url=http://en.chinagate.cn/2015-04/18/content_35357778.htm|title=30 killed in fighting between Hadi's forces, Houthis in Yemen's Taiz|work=chinagate.cn}} as well as three civilians.{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/871660/at-least-76-dead-in-yemen-air-raids-fighting/ |title=At least 76 dead in Yemen air raids, fighting |work=The Express Tribune |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418075100/http://tribune.com.pk/story/871660/at-least-76-dead-in-yemen-air-raids-fighting/ |archivedate=18 April 2015 }} Another report put the number of dead at 85.{{cite web|url=http://www.miningjournal.net/page/content.detail/id/831870/Yemen-militia-says-it-is-besieging-rebels-at-strategic-base.html?isap=1&nav=5016|title=Yemen militia says it is besieging rebels at strategic base|work=miningjournal.net}}{{Dead link|date=November 2015}} On the morning of 19 April, 10 more Houthi and four pro-Hadi fighters were killed.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-3045497/Clashes-Yemen-rebels-president-allies-kill-21.html|title=Yemen rebel leader vows resistance against Saudi-led air war|work=Mail Online}} A pro-Hadi official claimed 150 pro-Houthi and 27 tribal fighters had been killed in fighting in Ma'rib province between 2 and 21 April.{{cite web|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1875/news/5056/170-reported-dead-in-two-weeks-of-fighting-in-Marib.htm|title=170 reported dead in two weeks of fighting in Marib|work=Yemen Times}} On 4 September a Houthi missile hit an ammunition dump at a military base in Ma'rib killing 45 UAE, 10 Saudi and 5 Bahraini soldiers.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-34163982|title=Yemen crisis: UAE launches fresh Yemen attacks|publisher=BBC.com|date=5 September 2015|accessdate=6 September 2015}} On 16 October, Houthis and allied forces reportedly seized control of a military base in the town of Mukayris, pushing opponents out of southern Bayda.{{cite news|url=http://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2015/10/16/yemen-rebels-push-pro-govt-troops-out-of-southern-province|title=Yemen officials say rebels have pushed pro-government troops out of southern Bayda province|publisher=U.S. News & World Report|date=16 October 2015|accessdate=16 October 2015}} On January 6, 2016, Hadi loyalists [[Battle of port Midi|captured]] the strategic port of [[Midi District]], but insurgents backed by the Houthi government continued making attacks in and around the city. ===Military intervention=== ====Saudi-led intervention in Yemen==== {{Main article|Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen}} In response to rumours that [[Saudi Arabia]] could intervene in Yemen, Houthi commander [[Ali al-Shami (Yemeni militant)|Ali al-Shami]] boasted on 24 March that his forces would invade the larger kingdom and not stop at [[Mecca]], but rather [[Riyadh]].{{cite news|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yemen-protests-against-militants-leave-one-dead-17-injured-1427193838|agency=The Wall Street Journal|title=Yemen’s Houthi Militants Extend Push Southward|first=Hakim|last=Almasmari|date=24 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} [[File:Saudi soldier from the First Brigade Airborne near to Emirates soldier.jpg|thumb|Saudi soldier from the First Airborne Brigade with Emirates soldier]] The following evening, Saudi Arabia began a military intervention alongside eight other [[Arab world|Arab states]] and with the logistical support of the [[United States]] against the Houthis, bombing positions throughout Sana'a. In a joint statement, the nations of the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] (with the exception of [[Oman]]) said they decided to intervene against the Houthis in Yemen at the request of Hadi's government.{{cite news|agency=Reuters|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/25/us-yemen-security-arabs-idUSKBN0ML1B420150325|title=Arab League to discuss Yemen intervention plea on Thursday|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2015/03/saudi-ambassador-announces-military-operation-yemen-150325234138956.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Saudi and Arab allies bomb Houthi positions in Yemen|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}{{vi}} [http://www.nguoi-viet.com/absolutenm2/templates/viewarticlesNVO.aspx?articleid=204942&zoneid=5#.VRQ7yvnF-zE Phiến quân Shiite tấn công, tổng thống Yemen bỏ chạy]. 2015-03-25. Retrieved 26 Mar 2015 [[Salman of Saudi Arabia|King Salman of Saudi Arabia]] declared the [[Royal Saudi Air Force]] to be in full control of Yemeni airspace within hours of the operation beginning.{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/03/26/GCC-states-to-repel-Houthi-aggression-in-Yemen-statement-.html|agency=Al Arabiya|title=Saudi warplanes bomb Houthi positions in Yemen|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}} The airstrikes were aimed at hindering the Houthis' advance toward Hadi's stronghold in southern Yemen.{{cite news|last1=Shaheen|first1=Kareem|last2=Kamali Dehghan|first2=Saeed|title=Gulf states consider Yemen ground offensive to halt Houthi rebel advance |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/26/gulf-states-yemen-ground-offensive-to-halt-houthi-rebel-advance|date=26 March 2015|agency=The Guardian}} [[Al Jazeera]] reported that [[Mohammed Ali al-Houthi]], a Houthi commander appointed in February as President of the [[Revolutionary Committee (Yemen)|Revolutionary Committee]], was injured by an airstrike in Sana'a on the first night of the campaign.{{cite news|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/3/25/houthi-aden.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Saudis launch air campaign to defend Yemen government|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=1 April 2015}} According to [[Reuters]], planes from [[Egypt]], [[Morocco]], [[Jordan]], [[Sudan]], [[Kuwait]], [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Qatar]], and [[Bahrain]] are also taking part in the operation. [[Iran]] condemned the Saudi-led airstrikes and urged an immediate end to attacks on Yemen.{{cite news|title=Iran's Zarif urges immediate end to Saudi attacks on Yemen|url=http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2015/03/26/403426/Iran-slams-Saudiled-invasion-of-Yemen|date=16 March 2015}} Saudi Arabia requested that [[Pakistan]] commit forces as well, but [[Parliament of Pakistan|Pakistan's parliament]] officially voted to remain neutral.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/10/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0N10LO20150410|agency=Reuters|title=Pakistan declines Saudi call for armed support in Yemen fight|date=10 April 2015|accessdate=10 April 2015|first=Mohammed|last=Mukhashaf}} However, Pakistan agreed to provide support in line with a [[United Nations Security Council]] resolution, dispatching warships to enforce an [[arms embargo]] against the Houthis.{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/874469/crisis-in-arabian-peninsula-pakistan-unlikely-to-budge-on-yemen/|title=Crisis in Arabian Peninsula: Pakistan unlikely to budge on Yemen|date=23 April 2015|accessdate=23 April 2015}} The bombing campaign was officially declared over on 21 April, with Saudi officials saying they would begin ''Operation Restoring Hope'' as a combination of political, diplomatic, and military efforts to end the war.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/22/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0NC2LD20150422|agency=Reuters|title=Saudis end air campaign in Yemen, seek political solution|first=Noah|last=Browning|date=22 April 2015|accessdate=21 April 2015}} Even still, airstrikes continued against Houthi targets, and fighting in Aden and [[Ad Dali']] went on.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/23/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0NC2LD20150423|agency=Reuters|title=Saudi-led coalition launches air strikes throughout Yemen: residents|date=23 April 2015|accessdate=23 April 2015}} ====Arab League==== In [[Egypt]], the Yemeni foreign minister called for an [[Arab League]] military intervention against the Houthis. Egyptian President [[Abdel Fattah al-Sisi]] floated the idea of a unified military force.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} The Arab League announced the formation of a unified military force to respond to conflict in Yemen and Libya.{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/29/mideast-arabs-communique-idUSL6N0WV03T20150329|title=Arab summit agrees on unified military force for crises|publisher=Reuters|date=29 March 2015}} ====Drone strikes==== {{See also|Terrorism in Yemen#US air attacks|List of drone strikes in Yemen}} Since the mid-2000s, the [[United States]] has been carrying out targeted killings of [[jihad]]ist militants and ideologues in [[Yemen]], although the U.S. government generally does not confirm involvement in specific attacks conducted by [[unmanned aerial vehicle]]s as a matter of policy.{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/us-silence-on-drone-strikes-comes-under-pressure-after-hostage-deaths/2015/04/24/cb48e9d4-eaa7-11e4-aae1-d642717d8afa_story.html|agency=The Washington Post|title=U.S. government’s refusal to discuss drone attacks comes under fire|date=24 April 2015|accessdate=7 May 2015}} During the civil war in Yemen, drone strikes have continued, targeting wanted leaders of [[Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]]. [[Ibrahim al-Rubeish]] and [[Nasser bin Ali al-Ansi]], two leading AQAP figures, were killed by U.S. drone strikes in the vicinity of [[Al Mukalla]] in May.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/15/world/middleeast/us-drone-kills-a-top-figure-in-al-qaedas-yemen-branch.html?_r=1|agency=The New York Times|title=U.S. Drone Kills a Top Figure in Al Qaeda's Yemen Branch|date=14 April 2015|accessdate=7 May 2015|first=Scott|last=Shane}}{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/07/yemen-al-qaida-droke-strike-charlie-hebdo|agency=The Guardian|title=Al-Qaida in Yemen says US drone killed man who claimed Charlie Hebdo attack|date=7 May 2015|accessdate=7 May 2015}} Approximately 240 AQAP militants have been killed by American drone strikes since the civil war began.[http://www.longwarjournal.org/multimedia/Yemen/code/Yemen-strike.php "Long War Journal: Yemen"]. ===Islamic State presence and operations=== The Islamic State has proclaimed several provinces in Yemen and has urged its adherents to wage war against the Houthi movement, as well as against Zaydis in general.{{cite news|url=http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/ISIS%20INTSUM_Final.pdf|agency=Institute for the Study of War|title=ISIS Global Intelligence Summary March 1 - May 7|date=10 May 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}} ISIS militants have conducted bombing attacks in various parts of the country, particularly against mosques in Sana'a.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-31989844|agency=BBC|title=Yemen crisis: Islamic State claims Sanaa mosque attacks|date=21 March 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/06/us-yemen-security-blast-idUSKCN0S02CV20151006|agency=Reuters|title=Seven killed in Islamic State suicide bombing in Yemeni capital|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}} On 6 October 2015, IS militants conducted a series of suicide bombings in Aden that killed 15 soldiers affiliated with the Hadi government and the Saudi-led coalition.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/06/us-yemen-security-aden-hotel-idUSKCN0S009E20151006|agency=Reuters|title=Islamic State claims suicide attacks on Yemeni government, Gulf troops|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}} The attacks were directed against the al-Qasr hotel, which had been a headquarters for pro-Hadi officials, and also military facilities. Prior to the claim of responsibility by the Islamic State, officials from the UAE attributed the damage to rockets fired by forces loyal to the Houthis and Ali Abdullah Saleh. ===May 2015 truce=== {{main article|Yemeni crisis reconciliation attempts}} A five-day ceasefire proposed by Saudi Arabia was accepted by the Houthis and their allies in the military on 10 May 2015. The ceasefire was intended to allow the delivery of humanitarian aid to the country.{{cite news|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yemens-houthi-rebels-accept-five-day-truce-proposal-1431250255|agency=The Wall Street Journal|title=Yemen’s Houthi Rebels Accept Five-Day Truce Proposal|date=10 May 2015|accessdate=10 May 2015}} The temporary truce began on the night of 12 May to allow the delivery of food, water, medical, and fuel aid throughout the country.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-32719194|agency=BBC News|title=Yemen conflict: Aid effort begins as truce takes hold|date=13 May 2015|accessdate=13 May 2015}} On the fourth day of the truce, the fragile peace unraveled as fighting broke out in multiple southern governorates. At least three civilians in [[Aden]] and 12 in [[Taiz]] were killed on 16 May, despite the ceasefire.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/fighting-rages-yemen-4th-day-humanitarian-truce-31092753|agency=ABC News|title=Fighting Rages in Yemen on 4th Day of Humanitarian Truce|first=Ahmed|last=Al-Haj|date=16 May 2015|accessdate=16 May 2015}} [[Agence France-Presse]] reported that "dozens" were killed in southern Yemen by the clashes, including 26 Houthi and 12 pro-Hadi fighters.{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20150516-south-yemen-clashes-kill-dozens-ceasefire-nears-end |agency=France 24 |title=South Yemen clashes kill dozens as ceasefire nears end |date=16 May 2015 |accessdate=16 May 2015 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} ====Omani Initiative==== Around this same time reports surfaced in the media suggesting that [[Oman]], which is the only Middle Eastern Monarchy not taking part in the coalition and has a border with Yemen, has presented a 7-point plan to both Iran and Saudi Arabia. Oman has played a vital role as a bridge between Tehran and the West in the past to help in the nuclear negotiations and thus enjoys good relations with Iran as well as its GCC neighbors. It has also been suggested that Oman was responsible to mediate a 24-hour ceasefire although analysts doubt if Oman can help bring about more rigid negotiations.{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/05/oman-response-yemen-conflict.html#| title=Oman breaks from GCC on Yemen conflict|work=Al-Monitor: the Pulse of the Middle East| accessdate=25 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2015/4/24/oman-offers-seven-point-peace-plan-for-yemen|title=Oman offers seven-point peace plan for Yemen|author=Al-Araal-Jadeed staff|work=alaraby|accessdate=25 September 2015}} The following parts constituted the planned initiative: * The withdrawal of the Houthis and forces loyal to deposed president Ali Abdullah Saleh from all Yemeni cities and the return of military hardware and munitions seized from the Yemeni Army. * The restoration of the president Abd Rabbo Mansour Hadi and the government of Khalid Bahah. * Early parliamentary and presidential elections. * An agreement signed by all Yemeni parties. * The conversion of [[Houthis|Ansarullah]] into a political party. * An international aid conference attended by donor states. * Yemen entering the Gulf Cooperation Council. ===Sabeen square mass demonstration=== Over 900,000 Yemenis demonstrators gathered in [[Sana'a]]’s Sabeen square on Saturday 20 August government|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-yemen-rebel-march-20160820-snap-story.html|accessdate=21 August 2016|work=latimes.com|date=21 August 2016}} Protesters waved Yemen flag and News|agency=BBC}} The rally is considered "one of the biggest" demonstrations in Yemen since the break out of the civil war.{{cite news|last1=Staff writers|title=PressTV-Saudi jets strike mass rally in Sana'a|url=http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2016/08/20/480887/Saudi-warplanes-strike-mass-rally-in-Yemeni-capital|accessdate=21 August 2016|work=Press TV}}{{cite news|last1=Staff writers|title=Shia Guardian|agency=Reuters in Riyadh|date=20 August 2016}} ==Humanitarian situation== {{see also|Human rights violations during the Yemeni Civil War (2015-present)}} [[CNN]] reported on 8 April that almost 10,160,000 Yemenis were deprived of water, food, and electricity as a result of the conflict. The report also added per sources from [[UNICEF]] officials in Yemen that within 15 days, some 100,000 people across the country were dislocated, while Oxfam said that more than 10 million Yemenis did not have enough food to eat, in addition to 850,000 half-starved children. Over 13 million civilians were without access to clean water.{{cite web |author=Tim Lister | url= http://edition.cnn.com/2015/04/08/middleeast/yemen-saudi-6-things-lister/index.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+rss%2Fedition_world+%28RSS%3A+CNNi+-+World%29 | title=The war in Yemen is getting worse – and a civilian catastrophe is looming | publisher=CNN.Com | date=8 April 2015 | accessdate=8 April 2015}}{{cite web |author= Maria abi-habib |url= http://www.wsj.com/articles/humanitarian-crisis-deepens-in-embattled-yemen-city-1428340706 |title=Humanitarian Crisis Deepens in Embattled Yemen City |publisher=The Wall Street Journal | date=6 April 2015 |accessdate= 8 April 2015}} A medical aid boat brought 2.5 tonnes of medicine to [[Aden]] on 8 April.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/afp-medical-aid-boat-docks-in-yemens-aden-2015-4|agency=Business Insider|title=Medical aid boat docks in Yemen's Aden|date=8 April 2015|accessdate=10 April 2015}} A UNICEF plane loaded with 16 tonnes of supplies landed in [[Sana'a]] on 10 April.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/10/middleeast/yemen-crisis/|agency=CNN|title=UNICEF: Shipment of medical supplies, other aid reaches Yemen's capital|first=Don|last=Melvin}} The [[United Nations]] announced on 19 April that [[Saudi Arabia]] promised to provide $273.7 million in emergency humanitarian aid to Yemen. The UN appealed for the aid, saying 7.5 million people had been affected by the conflict and many were in need of medical supplies, potable water, food, shelter, and other forms of support.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2015/04/19/fighting-airstrikes-hit-across-yemen-as-saudi-arabia-pledges-aid/|agency=Fox News|title=Fighting, airstrikes hit across Yemen as Saudi Arabia pledges aid|date=19 April 2015|accessdate=19 April 2015}} On 12 May, [[Oxfam]] warned that the five days a humanitarian ceasefire was scheduled to last would not be sufficient to fully address Yemen's humanitarian crisis. It has also been said that the Houthis are collecting a war tax on goods. The political analyst Abdulghani al-Iryani affirmed that this tax is: "an illegal levy, mostly extortion that is not determined by law and the amount is at the discretion of the field commanders".{{cite web|last1=chronicle.fanack.com|title=Yemeni People Suffer as the World Turns its Back|url=https://chronicle.fanack.com/yemen/history-past-to-present/yemeni-people-suffer-as-the-world-turns-its-back/|website=fanack.com|accessdate=27 July 2015}} As the war dragged on through the summer and into the fall, things were made far worse when [[Cyclone Chapala]], the equivalent of a category 2 Hurricane,{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.com/storms/hurricane/news/cyclone-chapala-yemen-oman-arabian-peninsula|title=Cyclone Chapala a Rare, Destructive Landfall in Yemen|date=29 October 2015|work=The Weather Channel|accessdate=18 November 2015}} made landfall on 3 November. ===War crime accusations=== [[File:Destroyed house in the south of Sanaa 12-6-2015-4.jpg|thumb|Destroyed house in the south of Sanaa, 13 June 2015]] According to [[Farea Al-Muslim]], direct war crimes have been committed during the conflict; for example, an [[Internally displaced person|IDP]] camp was hit by a Saudi airstrike, while Houthis have sometimes prevented aid workers from giving aid.{{cite web|last=Kasinof|first=Laura|title=How Yemen’s Civil Conflict Turned Into a Regional Proxy War |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/206161/how-yemens-civil-conflict-turned-regional-proxy-war|work=[[The Nation]]}} The [[UN]] and several major human rights groups discussed the possibility that war crimes may have been committed by Saudi Arabia during the air campaign.{{cite web|title=Human Rights Watch: Saudi-Led Coalition Bombing Yemen with Banned U.S.-Made Cluster Munitions|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2015/5/5/human_rights_watch_saudi_led_coalition|date=}} [[Human Rights Watch]] (HRW) wrote that the Saudi-led air campaign that began on 26 March 2015, had "conducted airstrikes in apparent violation of the [[Law of war|laws of war]], such as the March 30 attack on a displaced persons camp in Mazraq, northern Yemen, that struck a medical facility and a market". HRW also said that the Houthis had "unlawfully deployed forces in densely populated areas and used excessive force against peaceful protesters and journalists". In addition, HRW said that by providing logistical and intelligence assistance to coalition forces, "the United States may have become a party to the conflict, creating obligations under the laws of war".{{cite web|title=Saudi Coalition/US: Curb Civilian Harm in Yemen |url=http://www.hrw.org/news/2015/04/13/saudi-coalitionus-curb-civilian-harm-yemen | work=Human Rights Watch | accessdate=2015-05-07 | date=2015-04-13 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YM3xkrhp | archivedate = 2015-05-07| deadurl=no}} Other incidents noted by HRW that had been deemed as "indiscriminate or disproportionate" or "in violation of the laws of war" were: a strike on a dairy factory outside the Red Sea port of Hodaida (31 civilian deaths);{{cite web|title=Yemen: Factory Airstrike Killed 31 Civilians – Saudi-Led, US-Backed Attack Raises Laws-of-War Concerns |url=http://www.hrw.org/news/2015/04/15/yemen-factory-airstrike-killed-31-civilians | work=Human Rights Watch | accessdate=2015-05-11 | date=2015-04-16 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YReY2gXI | archivedate = 2015-05-11| deadurl=no}} a strike that destroyed a humanitarian aid warehouse of the international aid organization Oxfam in Saada;{{cite web|title=Yemen: Warehouse Strike Threatens Aid Delivery – Inquiry Still Needed If Saudi-Led Bombing Campaign Ends |url=http://www.hrw.org/news/2015/04/22/yemen-warehouse-strike-threatens-aid-delivery | work=Human Rights Watch | accessdate=2015-05-09 | date=2015-04-23 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YOg2D59t | archivedate = 2015-05-09| deadurl=no}} the Saudi Arabia-led coalition’s blockade of Yemen which kept out fuel desperately needed for the Yemeni population’s survival.{{cite web|title=Yemen: Coalition Blocking Desperately Needed Fuel – Tankers Wait Offshore as Civilians Go Without Water, Electricity |url=http://www.hrw.org/news/2015/05/10/yemen-coalition-blocking-desperately-needed-fuel | work=Human Rights Watch | accessdate=2015-05-11 | date=2015-05-11 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YRaXE0wz | archivedate = 2015-05-11| deadurl=no}} [[Amnesty International]] said that several Saudi Arabian–led airstrikes, documented by it, hit five densely populated areas ([[Sa'dah]], [[Sana'a]], [[Hodeidah]], [[Hajjah]] and [[Ibb]]), and "raise concerns about compliance with the rules of international humanitarian law".{{cite web|title=Yemen: Relentless airstrikes that have left hundreds of civilians dead must be investigated |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/articles/news/2015/04/yemen-investigate-relentless-airstrikes-that-have-left-hundreds-of-civilians-dead/ | work=Amnesty International | accessdate=2015-05-12 | date=2015-04-24 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YT8xuO0U | archivedate = 2015-05-12| deadurl=no}}{{cite web|title=Yemen: Mounting evidence of high civilian toll of Saudi-led airstrikes |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/articles/news/2015/05/yemen-mounting-evidence-of-high-civilian-toll-of-saudi-led-airstrikes/ | work=Amnesty International | accessdate=2015-05-12 | date=2015-05-08 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YSxJL2Z7 | archivedate = 2015-05-12| deadurl=no}} Amnesty International added, that according to its research, at least 139 people, including at least 97 HRW also said that pro-Houthi fighters may have committed war crimes when two women were killed in Yemen and aid workers were arrested for two weeks.{{cite web|title=Yemen: Pro-Houthi Forces Attack, Detain Civilians| url=http://www.hrw.org/news/2015/05/07/yemen-pro-houthi-forces-attack-detain-civilians | work=Human Rights Watch | accessdate=2015-05-11 | date=2015-05-07 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YRj7RBrI | archivedate = 2015-05-11| deadurl=no}} U.N. Humanitarian Coordinator for Yemen, Johannes van der Klaauw, said that air strikes by the Saudi-led coalition on Sa’ada city in Yemen, where many civilians were trapped, were in breach of [[international humanitarian law]], despite calls for civilians to leave the area. Scores of civilians were reportedly killed and thousands forced to flee their homes after the Saudi-led coalition declared the entire governorate a military target, he said.{{cite web|last=Miles|first=Tom|title=Saudi-led strikes in Yemen break international law: U.N. coordinator |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/09/us-yemen-security-saudi-un-idUSKBN0NU0PN20150509 | work=Reuters U.S. | accessdate=2015-05-10 | date=2015-05-09 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YQIG6Yhe | archivedate = 2015-05-10| deadurl=no}}{{cite web|title=Statement by the Humanitarian Coordinator for Yemen, Johannes Van Der Klaauw (9 May 2015) [EN/AR] |url=http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/HC%20Statement%20on%20Yemen%209%20May%202015.pdf | work=reliefweb.int (original: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affair, UN Humanitarian Coordinator in Yemen) | accessdate=2015-05-10 | date=2015-05-09 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YQIG6Yhe | archivedate = 2015-05-10| deadurl=no}} Van der Klaauw also said that coalition strikes had targeted schools and hospitals, in breach of international law,{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/yemen-rebels-claim-tribal-allies-downed-moroccan-warplane/2015/05/11/27e895c4-f7df-11e4-a13c-193b1241d51a_story.html|title=Intense clashes in Yemen endanger prospects of humanitarian cease-fire|author=Erin Cunningham|date=11 May 2015|work=Washington Post|accessdate=29 June 2015}} [[File:Months after an airstrike on a neighborhood populated by black Yemenis or "Muhamasheen" more than a hundred buildings still remain in rubble and survivors continue to search for any valuables - Sanaa - Yemen - Oct-9-2015.png|thumb|Yemeni capital Sanaa after airstrikes, 9 October 2015]] A group of 17 aid agencies working in Yemen condemned the growing intensity of airstrikes in the north of Yemen on 8 and 9 May 2015. [[Save the Children]]’s Country Director in Yemen, Edward Santiago, said that the "indiscriminate attacks after the dropping of leaflets urging civilians to leave Sa'ada raises concerns about the possible pattern being established in breach of International Humanitarian Law".{{cite web|title=Aid Agencies Call For an Immediate and Permanent Cease Fire as an Additional 70,000 People Flee Coalition Airstrikes in Northern Yemen |url=http://www.savethechildren.org/site/apps/nlnet/content2.aspx?c=8rKLIXMGIpI4E&b=9241315&ct=14661497 | work=Save the Children | accessdate=2015-05-12 | date=2015-05-10 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/6YSJSbBZj | archivedate = 2015-05-12| deadurl=no}} Euro-Mediterranean Human Rights Monitor has claimed that [[Houthis|Houthi militias]] in alliance with the militants of exiled former president [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] killed purposely at least 22 civilians in [[Taiz]]. According to eyewitnesses, the militants launched [[Katyusha rocket launcher|Katyusha rockets]] targeting the markets and residential neighbourhoods in the center of Taiz. As a result, many civilians were killed and wounded. On the other hand, local media belonging to Houthi militias have denied such accusation, accusing [[Armed Forces of Saudi Arabia|Saudi]] and [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIS]] for committing these attacks.{{cite web|url = http://www.euromedmonitor.org/en/article/982/Humanitarian-catastrophe-is-imminent-in-Yemeni-city-of-Taiz-as-Houthis-target-civilians|title = Humanitarian catastrophe is imminent in yemeni city of taiz as houthis target civilians|website = Euro-Mediterranean Human Rights Monitor}} In December 2015, HRW claimed that six "unlawful airstrikes" were carried out in the capital by the Saudi-led coalition in September and October, which killed 60 civilians. They also criticized the United States, a party to the conflict, for refusing to investigate the attacks.[https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/12/21/yemen-coalition-bombs-homes-capital Yemen: Coalition Bombs Homes in Capital]. [[Human Rights Watch]]. December 21, 2015. In January 2016, local sources in the Yemeni capital of Sana'a reported that a Saudi-led coalition airstrike targeted the Noor Center for the Blind.{{cite web|url=https://www.rt.com/news/328024-yemen-saudi-airstrike-blind/|title=Yemen center for blind hit by Saudi-led coalition airstrike – locals|work=RT International}} On October 8, 2016, a Saudi-led airstrike on a funeral ceremony that killed roughly 100 people and injured 500, including children. October 13, 2016. ===Refugees=== [[Djibouti]], a small country in the [[Horn of Africa]] across the [[Bab-el-Mandeb]] strait from [[Yemen]], has received an influx of refugees since the start of the campaign.{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-03-30/djibouti-backs-military-intervention-in-yemen-la-nation-reports|title=Djibouti Backs Military Intervention in Yemen, La Nation Reports|agency=Bloomberg|date=30 March 2015|accessdate=3 April 2015|first=Paul|last=Richardson}}{{cite news|agency=CNN|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/09/middleeast/yemen-refugees-djibouti/index.html|date=9 April 2015|accessdate=9 April 2015|title='A window into hell:' Desperate Yemenis flee Saudi airstrikes by boat|first=Nima|last=Elbagir}} Refugees also fled from Yemen to [[Somalia]], arriving by sea in [[Somaliland]] and [[Puntland]] starting 28 March.{{cite news|url=http://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2015/03/31/fleeing-violence-in-yemen-refugees-arrive-in-somalia|agency=U.S. News and World Report|title=Fleeing violence at home, dozens of Yemeni refugees arrive in Somalia|first=Abdi|last=Guled|date=31 March 2015|accessdate=3 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://news.vice.com/article/yemens-conflict-is-getting-so-bad-that-some-yemenis-are-fleeing-to-somalia|agency=VICE News|title=Yemen’s Conflict is Getting So Bad that Some Yemenis Are Fleeing to Somalia|first=Alice|last=Speri|date=2 April 2015|accessdate=3 April 2015}} On 16 April 2015, 2,695 refugees of 48 nationalities were reported to have fled to [[Oman]] in the past two weeks.{{cite news |url=http://www.zawya.com/story/Oman_receives_2695_Yemen_refugees_in_two_weeks-GN_16042015_170438/ |title=Oman receives 2,695 Yemen refugees in two weeks |work=[[Zawya]] |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=16 April 2015 |accessdate=18 April 2015}} According to Asyam Hafizh, an [[Indonesian people|Indonesian]] student who was studying in Yemen, Al-Qaeda of Yemen has rescued at least 89 Indonesian civilians which trapped in the conflict. 1.jpg|thumb|Registration of [[India]]n citizens evacuating from Yemen in March, 2015.]] The [[Royal Saudi Navy]] evacuated diplomats and [[United Nations]] staff from Aden to [[Jeddah]] on 28 March.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/28/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0ML0YC20150328|agency=Reuters|title=Diplomats and U.N. staff flee Yemen as Houthis target Aden|date=28 March 2015|accessdate=28 March 2015}} [[Pakistan]] dispatched two special [[Pakistan International Airlines|PIA flights]] to [[Evacuation of Pakistani citizens from Yemen during the Yemeni crises|evacuate]] some 500 [[Pakistanis in Yemen|stranded Pakistanis]] on 29 March 2015.{{cite news|title=Pakistan evacuates hundreds during pause in Yemen strikes – Saudi official|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2015/03/29/yemen-security-pakistan-idINKBN0MP05G20150329|accessdate=29 March 2015|publisher=Reuters|date=29 March 2015}} Several UN staff members and Arab diplomats were also evacuated following the airstrikes.{{cite news|title=Saudi Diplomats, U.N. Officials Evacuate Yemen|url=http://www.newsweek.com/saudi-un-officials-evacuate-yemen-317576|accessdate=29 March 2015|work=Newsweek|date=29 March 2015}} The [[India]]n government responded by deploying ships and planes to Yemen to evacuate stranded Indians.
