The UN children's agency reported 62 children killed and 30 injured and also children being recruited as soldiers.{{cite web|last1=AFP|title=UN to consider pause in Yemen bombing as death toll rises|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/yemen/11515284/UN-to-consider-pause-in-Yemen-bombing-as-death-toll-rises.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=14 April 2015}} [[Russia]] called for "humanitarian pauses" in the coalition bombing campaign, bringing the idea before the [[United Nations Security Council]] in a 4 April emergency meeting.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/russia-urges-call-humanitarian-pause-yemen-30099311|agency=ABC News|title=Russia Urges UN to Call for 'Humanitarian Pause' in Yemen|first=Edith|last=Lederer|date=4 April 2015|accessdate=9 April 2015}} However, Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United Nations questioned whether humanitarian pauses would be the best way of delivering humanitarian assistance.{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/04/04/uk-yemen-security-russia-idUKKBN0MV0JU20150404|title=Russia calls for pause in Yemen air strikes to evacuate foreigners|work=Reuters UK}} On 14 April, the [[United Nations Security Council]] adopted a resolution placing sanctions on [[Abdul-Malik al-Houthi]] and [[Ahmed Ali Saleh]], establishing an [[arms embargo]] on the Houthis, and calling on the Houthis to quit Sana'a and other areas they seized.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/15/middleeast/yemen-crisis/index.html|agency=CNN|title=Three weeks of Saudi strikes in Yemen, no peace in sight|first=Don|last=Melvin|date=15 April 2015|accessdate=15 April 2015}} The Houthis condemned the UN resolution and called for mass protests.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/04/imposes-arms-embargo-yemen-rebels-150414140733146.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Houthis condemn UN resolution on Yemen|date=15 April 2015|accessdate=15 April 2015}} [[Jamal Benomar]], the UN envoy to Yemen who brokered the deal that ended [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]]'s presidency during the [[Yemeni Revolution|2011–12 revolution]], resigned on 15 April.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/16/us-yemen-security-un-idUSKBN0N62O020150416|agency=Reuters|title=U.N. envoy to Yemen resigns|date=16 April 2015|accessdate=16 April 2015}} Mauritanian diplomat [[Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed]], formerly the head of the UN's Ebola response mission, was confirmed as the new UN Envoy to Yemen on 25 April.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/25/us-yemen-security-un-idUSKBN0NG0QI20150425|title=U.N. chief appoints Mauritanian diplomat as new Yemen envoy|date=25 April 2015|work=Reuters}} ==Other calls for ceasefire== {{main article|Yemeni crisis reconciliation attempts}} On 4 April, the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] called for a 24-hour ceasefire to deliver aid and supplies after the Saudi-led coalition blocked three aid shipments to Yemen.{{cite web|url=https://www.icrc.org/en/document/yemen-humanitarian-pause|title=Yemen: Immediate 24-hour humanitarian pause needed to bring in medical help|work=International Committee of the Red Cross}} On 5 April, [[Reuters]] quoted a Houthi leader as saying the group would be willing to sit down for peace talks if the airstrikes stopped and a neutral party acted as mediator.{{cite news | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/05/us-yemen-security-houthis-idUSKBN0MW0F020150405|agency=Reuters|title=Yemen's Houthis ready for talks if air strikes stop: senior member|first=Yara|last=Bayoumy|date=5 April 2015|accessdate=9 April 2015}} On 7 April, [[China]] added its support of a ceasefire in Yemen, following an appeal by the [[ICRC]] and [[Russia]] for a humanitarian pause.{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2015/04/07/yemen-security-china-idINKBN0MY0LV20150407|title=China adds voice to call for Yemen ceasefire|work=Reuters India|date=7 April 2015|accessdate=7 April 2015}} Despite [[Saudi Arabia]] asking for Pakistan's support to join the coalition,{{cite news|last1=Riedel|first1=Bruce|title=Why Pakistan Said No to King Salman|url=http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/04/14/why-pakistan-said-no-to-king-salman|accessdate=15 April 2015|agency=USA News|publisher=USA News|date=15 April 2015}} the [[Pakistan Government|Pakistan government]] has also called for a ceasefire in order to help negotiate a diplomatic solution.{{cite news|last1=Shahzad|first1=Asif|title=Pakistani premier urges Iran to help bring Yemen's Shiite rebels to negotiations|url=http://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2015/04/13/pakistani-pm-urges-iran-to-persuade-yemens-rebels-to-talks|accessdate=14 April 2015|agency=USA Today|publisher=USA Today, Asif|date=13 April 2015}} Alongside [[Turkey]], Pakistan has taken initiatives to arrange a ceasefire in Yemen.{{cite news|last1=Hussain|first1=Tom|title=How long can Pakistan stay out of Yemen fight in face of Saudi pressure?|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2015/04/13/263004/how-long-can-pakistan-stay-out.html|accessdate=14 April 2015|agency=McClatchy|publisher=McClatchy Foreign Staff|date=13 April 2015}} Analysis written in [[U.S. News & World Report|''U.S. News'']], Pakistan's [[Threat Matrix (database)|strategic calculations]] firmly believes that if the [[Saudi Arabian Army|Saudis]] enter into a [[Ground warfare|ground war]] in Yemen– with or without [[Pakistani military]]– it will become a [[stalemate]]; therefore, Pakistan is increasing its efforts to potentially help [[Engineering analysis|engineer]] a face-saving solution to achieve a ceasefire and end the war. On 12 April, Saudi Arabia rejected [[Iran]]'s request about a ceasefire in Yemen. [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Saudi Arabia)|Saudi Foreign Minister]] [[Saudi Prince|Prince]] [[Saud bin Faisal bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|Saud al-Faisal]] said in the Saudi capital, [[Riyadh]], at a news conference with his [[France|French]] [[French Foreign Minister|counterpart]] [[Laurent Fabius]], that "[[Saudi Arabia]] is a responsible for establishing legitimate government in Yemen and Iran should not interfere."{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/12/yemen-war-saudi-arabia-ceasefire_n_7049570.html | title=Saudi Arabia Dismisses Iran Calls For Yemen Ceasefire | publisher=huffingtonpost | date=12 April 2015 | accessdate=13 April 2015 | author=Mukhashaf and McDowall, Mohammed and Angus}} [[Australia]] called for the ceasefire in Yemen, because of the civilian casualties numbers.{{cite web | url=http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2015/apr/12/australia-calls-for-yemen-ceasefire-on-eve-of-julie-bishops-visit-to-iran | title=Australia calls for Yemen ceasefire on eve of Julie Bishop's visit to Iran | publisher=The Guardian | date=12 April 2015 | accessdate=13 April 2015 | author=Hurst Daniel}} On 16 April, Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] requested an immediate ceasefire in Yemen. Also he said all parties must stop war as soon as possible.{{cite web | url=http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=50601#.VTEnj9yUd9Q | title=In Washington, UN chief calls for immediate ceasefire by all parties in Yemen | publisher=Un News Center | date=16 April 2015 | accessdate=17 April 2015}} Iranian foreign minister [[Mohammad Javad Zarif]] submitted four-point Yemen peace plan to United Nations. In this letter he pointed to enormous civilian casualties and destroying civilian infrastructure. He said the only way for stopping the war is making condition that allows to Yemeni parties to form a national unity government without any foreign military intervention.{{cite web | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/17/us-yemen-security-iran-idUSKBN0N823820150417 | title=Iran submits four-point Yemen peace plan to United Nations | publisher=reuters | date=17 April 2015 | accessdate=20 April 2015 | author=Charbonneau Louis}} Furthermore, since 21 April 2016, peace talks have started in Kuwait at the Bayan Palace.{{cite web|title=Yemen Peace Talks: Drafting a Roadmap to a Destination Unknown|url=https://chronicle.fanack.com/yemen/history-past-to-present/war-in-yemen/yemen-peace-talks/|website=Fanack.com|accessdate=20 July 2016}} In June 2015, a solution to ending the Saudi intervention in Yemen sought the participation of a Yemeni delegation to the Geneva peace talks; the delegation came under attack in the Geneva peace talks.{{cite web | url=http://en.abna24.com/service/middle-east-west-asia/archive/2015/06/19/696106/story.html | title=Houthi Delegation Came under Attack in Geneva Peace Talks + Pics | publisher=ABNA| date=19 June 2015}} In 10 of April 2016, cease fire agreement reached in Yemen, after months of negotiation.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-36011794http://www.wsj.com/articles/saudi-led-coalition-promises-to-adhere-to-yemen-cease-fire-1460359998 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=11 April 2016 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}} ==Other developments== Armed Houthis ransacked [[Al Jazeera]]'s news bureau in Sana'a on 27 March, amid [[Qatar]]'s participation in the [[Saudi-led intervention in Yemen (2015–present)|military intervention]] against the group. The Qatar-based news channel condemned the attack on its bureau.{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/saudi-led-airstrikes-continue-for-second-day-in-yemen/2696496.html|agency=Voice of America|title=Egyptian, Saudi Vessels Approach Yemen Coast|first=Edward|last=Yeranian|date=27 March 2015|accessdate=27 March 2015}} On 28 March, [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] stated neither he nor anyone in his family would run for president, despite recent campaigning by his supporters for his son [[Ahmed Saleh|Ahmed]] to seek the presidency. He also called on [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi]] to step down as president and said new elections should be held.{{cite news|title=Ex-Yemeni Leader Urges Truce and Successor’s Ouster|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/29/world/middleeast/saudi-arabia-evacuates-diplomats-from-yemeni-city-as-houthi-advance-continues.html?_r=0|date=28 March 2015|accessdate=28 March 2015|agency=The New York Times}} Rumours about Saleh's whereabouts have swirled during the conflict. Foreign Minister [[Riyad Yassin]], a Hadi loyalist, claimed on 4 April that Saleh left Yemen aboard a [[Russia]]n aircraft [[International reactions to the Saudi-led intervention in Yemen (2015–present)|evacuating]] foreign nationals from [[Sana'a International Airport]].{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/yemeni-troops-retake-other-provinces-al-qaeda-rules-mukalla-port-city-2129445977|agency=Middle East Eye|title=Yemeni troops retake provinces as al-Qaeda captures port city of Mukalla|date=4 April 2015|accessdate=4 April 2015}} Later in the month, Saleh reportedly asked the Saudi-led coalition for a "safe exit" for himself and his family, but the request was turned down.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/04/yemeni-leader-asks-gulf-states-safe-exit-150415182159599.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Former Yemeni leader asks Gulf states for safe exit|date=16 April 2015|accessdate=16 April 2015}} [[Salman of Saudi Arabia|King Salman]] reshuffled the Saudi cabinet on 28 April, removing [[Muqrin of Saudi Arabia|Prince Muqrin]] as his designated successor. The Saudi royal palace said Muqrin had asked to step down, without giving a reason, but media speculation was that Muqrin did not demonstrate sufficient support for the Saudi-led military campaign in Yemen.{{cite news|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/2015/04/28/3765544/saudi-king-names-counterterrorism.html |agency=The News Tribune |title=Saudi king, facing challenges in Yemen, fires his heir, foreign minister |first=Tom |last=Hussain |date=28 April 2015 |accessdate=30 April 2015 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} A spokesman for Yemen's exiled government told [[Reuters]] on 29 April that the country would officially seek membership in the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]].{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/29/us-yemen-security-gulf-idUSKBN0NK1D220150429|agency=Reuters|title=Yemen government to request membership in GCC: official Yemeni spokesman|date=29 April 2015|accessdate=29 April 2015}} Media reports have noted that the civil war has reached nearly all of Yemen, with one notable exception being the remote [[Indian Ocean]] archipelago of [[Socotra]].{{cite news|url=http://triblive.com/usworld/betsyhiel/8131558-74/island-war-yemen#axzz3X2XX5Uex|agency=TribLive|title=Socotra islanders prize peace in sea away from Yemen's civil war|first=Betsy|last=Hiel|date=11 April 2015|accessdate=11 April 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/times-insider/2015/04/10/when-al-qaeda-stormed-my-city-reporters-notebook/?_r=0|agency=The
